original_title: More interest rate cuts needed for economy to recover, says CB Governor
original_body_lines: Colombo (News 1st) – Central Bank Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe says that interest rates need to be reduced further for Sri Lanka's economy to recover, CNBC reported.

Weerasinghe said in an interview on Friday (7th), a day after a massive cut in policy rates, that there will be more rate cuts to come. It was the second consecutive month that the Central Bank has slashed rates.

“We should need a further reduction in interest rates on the basis of forward-looking inflation, forward-looking output gap. This shows we made the right decision,” Weerasinghe told CNBC’s "Squawk Box Asia".

“If you look at the future, forward-looking inflation, we see very clearly, end-of-July inflation will be 7% by single digit and by end of the year, [inflation] will be low single-digit,” Weerasinghe said.
Inflation, as measured by the Colombo Consumer Price Index, slowed sharply to 12% in June, after peaking at 70% last September.
The Colombo Stock Exchange's All Share Index jumped by about 8% this week after parliament passed a domestic debt restructuring plan that had been required for the IMF’s bailout package.
Sri Lanka’s total debt is now over $83 billion, including foreign debt of $41.5 billion and $42.1 billion of domestic debt.

“We hope that [rate cuts] can be some sort of support for the recovery for the second half of the year. And obviously, for the next full year, we expect the country to bounce back to positive territory,” he said.
The Sri Lankan economy contracted by 11.5% year-on-year in the first quarter of 2023, gross domestic product figures released last month showed, the fifth consecutive quarter of recession.
